text: Across the inky swell, a river of moonlight cuts a path t lonely fishing tug drifting with the tide. THE MERRY WIDO
A light bulb waltzes with the sway of the boat. Three sha Irish fishermen unwind after dinner, playing cards.
The eldest and scruffiest (the SKIPPER) reveals his hand young deckhand (GREG). Read 'em and weep.
You can't be serious?
Laughing, the Skipper unspools himself from the cramped t as he and ROY, the bloated first-mate, clamber above deck
Every bloody night.
Roy and the Skipper check the hauled in nets, until ...
A SILENT ARC OF LIGHT SLICES ACROSS THE SKY.     It caree downwards in a furious trajectory and --
BOOM!!   A mile off their port it collides with the sea.
Did you see that?
... Yeah.
A flare?
The Skipper watches the water.     Unsure.
Greg leaps on deck brandishing a clutch of cards.
Ye cheated! There's five aces!    I counted 'em!
The Skipper brushes past Greg, distracted.
Secure the lines.
GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011          2.
Greg looks to Roy.
Not so funny now, huh?
Roy plucks one of the five aces from Greg's hand and flip over. Its backing is red.
It's from a different deck, ya muppet.
He sticks it to Greg's damp forehead and carries on as ordered. Greg turns the remaining aces over. They're blue
... Shite.
Foam rises as bubbles crest violently. Closing in, the Me Widow casts its searchlight across the churning surf.
The Skipper steers carefully, holding a radio mic.

Haven Point. Haven Point. Haven Point. This is Fishing tug Merry Widow. Call sign echo whiskey niner ait fife. Position five nautical miles west of Erin Island. Responding to unknown distress flare. Over.
The Skipper pulls back on the throttle, sloshing to a sto
He taps the sonar screen.     A hazy shadow engulfs the r
Definitely something ...
Over there!
Roy shines his flashlight over the rail.
There's something in the water!
Suddenly Roy wheels overboard, yanked into the murky sea. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011           3.
The Skipper drops the mic and rushes to the rail with Gre
Roy!
Roy's glowing flashlight bobs in the water.
Can you see him?!
A hundred yards off on the opposite starboard side, far behind them, Roy surfaces SCREAMING!
Greg and the Skipper rush to the starboard rail.
Roy's gurgled, tortured cries mist in the air.
The Skipper snaps into action.   Seconds count.
Don't lose him!
Greg points, fixing Roy's position.
The Skipper grabs a lifebuoy, lights it up and throws.
Roy! Don't panic, mate.     Swim for the buoy!
C'mon, Roy, kick!
Roy's head strains the surface, his arms flailing in agon spasms ...
... And then silence as he goes under.   The sound of wat sloshes and laps against the hull.
The Skipper stares hopelessly at the water.      Greg's p hand trembles. He lowers it.
The Skipper shoves a lifejacket into Greg's chest.
Put it on.
What happened?
Just do it, boy.
Greg does, fumbling. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011          4.
The Skipper loads a flare gun and aims it overhead -- WHO The glowing red beacon graffities the starry sky.
Merry Widow. Merry Widow. This is Coastguard Haven Point. Please respond. Over.
Radio a mayday! (off Greg's hesitation) Move!
Greg scrambles back to the helm --
-- and snatches the radio mic.
Mayday-Mayday-Mayday.
Merry Widow, uh, echo whiskey niner ait fife. Man overboard. Man overboard. Emergency assistance required. Position --
The Skipper scans the glassy sea with a flashlight.
ROY?!   ROY?!
Subtly at first, the buoy's bight of rope twinges.    The Skipper sees it. His eyes narrow --
-- it jerks like a fishing line.    The Skipper grabs it reels it in.
C'mon, Roy, mate. Fight.  UNDERWATER
The buoy's rope moves towards the boat.
Suddenly the trawler keels steeply.     Greg grips the fi for support as debris rains on him.
Jesus Christ!
GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011
Received Mayday, Merry Widow. Emergency rescue team dispatched. How many aboard? Over.
Water laps over Greg's feet as the boat rights itself. surveys the flooded deck. The Skipper's gone.
Please hurry.
Hold your position, Merry Widow, rescue chopper on its way. Over.
Greg drops the mic and edges outside.
The deck swims with water.      Greg holds his breath, li
Skipper?
The abandoned C.B. mic swings to and fro.        Almost p
Merry Widow, how many aboard? Over.
Greg rounds the pilothouse, breathing heavily.
Suddenly what looks like a weird, headless black snake fe its way towards his boots. Greg turns and bolts.
He scrambles to the stern amongst the nets and snatches a gutting-knife with both hands.
Trapped against the rail, panting, he prays for help but
-- HE'S DRAGGED OVERBOARD.      His legs round in the air cascades into the sea.
Just beyond the Merry Widow, he surfaces gasping.
Oh Jesus.    Oh Jesus.   Oh Jes--
He's gone. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011       6.
In the moonlight the isolated Merry Widow reposes mournfu

text: CIARГЃN O'SHEA lies face down on a sofa. His bed for the night. He gropes a dry bottle of whiskey as a mobile phon RINGS. He stirs awake. It's no surprise he looks like shite, but to be fair he's not bad looking after a wash.
Uh ... Yeah?
Someone we'll meet later as SGT KENIFICK replies.
(via speaker phone) O'Shea, I take it you've left already because if you haven't, you're late. That ferry gets in at nine.
O'Shea rises, eyes closed.       Mouth dry.
Where are you?
... On the way.
So you're in the car?
... Yeah ...
So you're driving while on the phone?!
In the name of God, I don't b--
O'Shea hangs up and drops his whiskey bottle in a bin whe it CLATTERS with yesterday's bottle, and the day before's GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011          7.
An isolated house at the foothills of a mountain.    A wh Garda patrol jeep leaves the scene and --
-- rambles along the sunny coast.   At the wheel, O'Shea very hungover, droopy eyed Garda.
Lush green hills and whitewashed bungalows, pastel beache and multi-coloured fishing boats. Enchanting.
Colourful crowds of FAMILIES (TEENS, KIDS, PARENTS) file the MAINLAND FERRY as it lies moored in the harbour.
GARDA LISA NOLAN hustles through the masses dragging a trolley bag and passing a sign that reads:  OILEГЃN Г‰IRINN, CГ‰AD MГЌLE FГЃILTE Welcome to Erin Island
Lisa opens a map and wrestles with it in the wind.   Soon defeated, it blows out of her hands.
Shit!
She chases it as if running down a mugger but it lifts skyward and twirls haughtily in the air.
Suddenly inching towards her, driving with all the panach an abandoned shopping trolley, comes O'Shea. Bleary-eyed hunched over, he drops his window before her.
Well?
Howya. O'Shea, is it? CiarГЎn?     We spoke on the phone. I'm Garda Nolan, Lisa.
You're not serious?
She considers his bedraggled appearance.   He looks like wants to vomit on her. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011         8.
Yeah, well. Just being polite.
Are ya gettin' in or what?
I have a bag.
He pops the boot and gazes back at the road, waiting.
Tyres SPLASH and CRASH in the war against potholes.
The jeep follows the mountain road ...
Wincing, O'Shea hugs the wheel feeling every agonising bu A locket of Lisa's slick ponytail comes undone. She quick yanks it back giving herself a face lift in the process.
O'Shea belches under his breath and Lisa flinches.    She a packet of mints from her bag.
Would you like a mint?
O'Shea stares at them, then at her.    Barely reading the
Nah thanks, they give me heartburn.
He belches again as they jostle over another pothole. Lis drops her window and her hair erupts in the sea breeze.
O'Shea and Lisa arrive at the station.   Home from home.
Across the grassy dunes, DR JIM GLEESON walks his dog. Fo health practitioner, he just preaches. He flings a stick his eager collie and it gallops over a dune.
Dr Gleeson follows, rising over the hill and stops cold a sees across the strand: A POD OF PILOT WHALES LAY BEACHED GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011        9.
SGT KENIFICK wipes a thumb along his desk. On the verge o retirement he looks more like tourist in his sunshine hol garb. He rises to greet O'Shea and Lisa.
Garda Nolan, lovely to have you. O'Shea, you look like shite. Would you go way and shave.
(re. Kenifick's clothes) A bit eager aren't ya?
Smooth crossing?
Smoother than most.
Coffee?
That'd be great, thanks.
Lisa hands O'Shea a mug from her bag.    He regards it.
So what do you think of the place?
It's gorgeous, isn't it?
'Tis indeed.
And quiet as shite.
Kenifick and Lisa glance at O'Shea.
Milk?
Uhm, what kind?
Cows.
GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011           10
O'Shea and Lisa consider each other.     Lines firmly dra
I'll take it black, thanks.
Kenifick's mobile RINGS and he silences it.

So you can have my desk while I'm gone. O'Shea will tell you, 'tis mostly administrative, processing permits and that sort. You might catch the odd bit of commotion every now and then but half the island's leaving for the show in Dungary so it'll be dead all weekend.
I'm sure we can find something to do.
O'Shea rolls his eyes and passes Lisa her coffee.
Ta.
She takes it and sits at her desk, feeling her surroundin
(whispered to Kenifick) Is she really necessary?
You tell me.
Lisa carefully arranges her desk how she likes it.     Ne
You're only gone two weeks.      I can handle two weeks.
You could.     But you wouldn't.
Kenifick's mobile PINGS.      He checks the text message.
Don't be late, I said.      What did I say?
His phone RINGS again. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011          11.
I'm coming, I'm coming.    Right, I'm off.
Not a bother.
Rightio. Reports and files in the top drawer, anything you need, O'Shea will be here to show you round. O'Shea?
You're gonna miss your boat.
SlГЎn.
Kenifick leaves. An uncomfortable silence fills the air l two strangers in an elevator. Lisa sips her coffee. Hates it. O'Shea slumps at his desk, throws his feet up and sig
Kenifick barges back in and O'Shea falls over himself to straighten up, burning himself with his coffee.
Won't go far with no tickets.    See you in a fortnight. Be good.
He snatches them and leaves. O'Shea recovers and notices Lisa stifling a smile. The office phone RINGS and O'Shea sluggishly reaches for it. But Lisa beats him to it.
Garda Nolan.
At the dock PADDY BARRETT sorts his lobster traps.   All short is a parrot and a wooden leg.
His traps appear empty, some mangled, but before he can protest one of the oblong traps leaps. He watches it and like a magic trick it leaps again.
He squats down and gazes between the seaweed strewn cage. Nothing to be seen thanks to the seaweed. He prods it and lo, it shifts violently. Hopping mad.
Paddy rises, wipes his frowning forehead with his cap and gestures to a fisherman packing ice crates on the dock.
TADHG MURPHY saunters over.    An alpha male in a beta bo GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011            1
Take a look at this.
Paddy gently kicks the lobster trap, spurring it. On cue, haphazardly jumps across the wet dock. Tadhg snickers.
He's a biggun.
He's not a lobster.
Then what is it?
Paddy shrugs.   Tadhg kneels down and peers inside.
SPLAT! A GEYSER OF GOO SPRAYS IN HIS FACE!        Tadhg s to his feet, spitting furiously.
Oh ya bastard, Paddy!      Ya knew it was gonna do that.
I didn't.    On me life.
Tadhg wipes away the slime with his sweater.
Eurgh, the smell.
So what is it?
I dunno, it's a feckin octopus or something, it's covered in seaweed. But 'tis no feckin' lobster!
Tadhg stomps off.
An octopus?
Paddy considers the lobster trap, eyes flashing.
Lisa drives safely, under the limit.     A turning approa
Do I go...?
GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011   13.
O'Shea waits for the last second.
... Left.
Lisa turns sharply, amusing O'Shea.
So you're after the sarge's desk?
What makes you say that?
Just wondering.
Well, I'm not. I'd some holidays saved that needed to be taken and this posting came up and I thought sure what harm, why not? Can't hurt with the review board, you know?
O'Shea nods, sussing her out.
Where are you stationed?
Dublin Central.
And how's that working out for ya?
Great. We got drugs, muggings, murders and rapes. Always on the go.
Well you can relax, there's none of that here.
You never know. It's the quiet places where all the mad shit happens. Just open a paper.
O'Shea smirks out his window.   Lisa notices.
What?
GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011          14.
I bet you haven't missed a day of work in your life.
And should I be ashamed of that?
It's just a job.
Arriving at the beach, Lisa parks sharply sending O'Shea colliding with the dashboard. He recovers, stunned.
Seatbelt.    It is the law.
O'Shea and Lisa get out of the parked jeep.
O'Shea and Lisa trundle past some ONLOOKERS (folks we'll party with later) and head towards the whales. They ploug forward until they're upon Dr Gleeson.
In all me years, never seen anything like it.
Lisa Nolan, doctor Jim Gleeson. Resident physician.
Oh hello, love. How are ya?
Grand, thanks.
You wouldn't have any Aspirin on ya, would ya, Jim?
I've a few winegums? Would ya like a winegum?
You're all right.
Lisa moves deeper down the beach and O'Shea follows. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011         15.
I'd prefer it if you'd introduce me as Garda Nolan.
Ah, no one minds.
I do.
Lisa marches on, staggering awkwardly in the soft sand.
O'Shea and Lisa arrive by the whales and ADAM SMITH, Ph.D nods to O'Shea as they approach. Busy working.
What happened?
(writing in a pad) One second.
Lisa's eyes light up at Smith's dismissal of O'Shea. A kindred spirit. Once Smith's ready, he ignores O'Shea and removes a glove to shake Lisa's hand. So very English.
Smith.
Lisa.
O'Shea stares at her.   Typical.
Smith's a marine psychologist or something, did I get that right?
No.   It's marine ecology.
O'Shea shrugs, whatever.
That was quick.
More fortunate really. I'm based here doing studies for the department of the marine.
Smith hands O'Shea the tip of a tape measure. GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011       16.
Hold this, please.
O'Shea doesn't have a choice. Smith walks the length of t whales, stepping around Lisa and touching her as he goes.
So how long are you here?
Two weeks.
Oh, wonderful. Wonderful.   Are you staying nearby?
O'Shea interrupts, deliberately:
So are they dead?!
Hmm?   No, they're just sleeping.
Smith and Lisa share a smirk. O'Shea notices and lets the tape measure go, snapping back on Smith's fingers. Ouch.
Slipped.
O'Shea and Smith trade looks.
So what happened?
Well they're pilot whales. It happens with them from time to time but no one really knows why.
Lisa notes deep spider-vein gashes on the whales' bodies if they were whipped with a huge cat-o'-nine-tails.
What are those marks?
Not sure. Possible scratches off the rocks while washing up here.

GRABBERS - Production Draft (GOLD) 28/1/2011            1

It's a strange one all right.

A charming little shithole.

Daly?
